text:
Pennywise, the shape-shifting clown from Stephen King’s It, is really scary.

Just ask the kids who have to go up against him in this weekend’s big screen adaptation of the 1986 horror novel.

“Whenever I saw him I knew he was going to scare a lot of people,” Jeremy Ray Taylor says with a laugh.

In the new screen version from director Andy Muschietti, Pennywise is played by Bill Skarsgard, best known for his work on Hemlock Grove and the Divergent series.

Part one of It focuses on a misfit group of kids dubbed the Losers’ Club, who find themselves in a life or death battle against a demonic entity, whose history of murder and violence in Derry, Maine, dates back for centuries.

A proposed sequel will pick up after the events of film No. 1, with the Losers’ Club back as adults to fight “It” once again.

The cast at the centre of the film shared some thoughts on who should play them as adults in the sequel during a recent visit to Toronto.

Chosen Jacobs, who plays Mike, wants Black Panther star Chadwick Boseman to step into his shoes, while Taylor (Ben), would love to see Guardians of the Galaxy’s Chris Pratt play an older version of his character.

Stranger Things’ Finn Wolfhard envisions Bill Hader playing his wisecracking Richie, while Sophia Lillis wants to see her character Bev Marsh played by Jessica Chastain.

Jaeden Lieberher likes the idea of Christian Bale stepping into his shoes as Bill Denborough, and Wyatt Oleff wants Joseph Gordon Levitt to play Stanley Uris.

Muschietti has said in earlier interviews that the sequel, which will take place 27 years later, will allow for the kids to return in flashback scenes.

And while the cast knows that coulrophobia (fear of clowns) is bubbling up again because of the film, Wolfhard thinks that Pennywise has given the clowning industry a new revenue path.

“Look, we love clowns,” he says. “Maybe there’s a shortage right now, but after the movie comes out people will hire more clowns for different reasons… to scare people.”

It is in theatres now.
